text:
From: James, a servant of God and of the Lord Jesus, the Messiah.
To: The twelve tribes in the Dispersion.
Greetings.
speaker: Narrator

text: Consider it pure joy, my brothers, when you are involved in various trials,
speaker: Narrator

text: because you know that the testing of your faith produces endurance.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you must let endurance have its full effect, so that you may be mature and complete, lacking nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now if any of you lacks wisdom, he should ask God, who gives to everyone generously without a rebuke, and it will be given to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he must ask in faith, without any doubts, for the one who has doubts is like a wave of the sea that is driven and tossed by the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Such a person should not expect to receive anything from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is a double-minded man, unstable in all he undertakes.
speaker: Narrator

text: A brother of humble means should rejoice in his having been exalted,
speaker: Narrator

text: and a rich person in his having been humbled, because he will fade away like a wild flower.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the sun comes up with its scorching heat and dries up the grass. The flower in it drops off, and its beauty is gone. That is how the rich person will fade away in his pursuits.
speaker: Narrator

text: How blessed is the man who endures temptation! When he has passed the test, he will receive the victor’s crown of life that God has promised to those who keep on loving him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When someone is tempted, he should not say, “I am being tempted by God,” because God cannot be tempted by evil, nor does he tempt anyone.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, each person is tempted by his own desire, being lured and trapped by it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When that desire becomes pregnant, it gives birth to sin; and when that sin grows up, it gives birth to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not be deceived, my dear brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every generous act of giving and every perfect gift is from above and comes down from the Father who made the heavenly lights, in whom there is no inconsistency or shifting shadow.
speaker: Narrator

text: In accordance with his will he made us his children by the word of truth, so that we might become the most important of his creatures.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must understand this, my dear brothers. Everyone should be quick to listen, slow to speak, and slow to get angry.
speaker: Narrator

text: For human anger does not produce the righteousness that God desires.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, rid yourselves of everything impure and every expression of wickedness, and with a gentle spirit welcome the word planted in you that can save your souls.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep on being obedient to the word, and not merely being hearers who deceive themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if anyone hears the word but is not obedient to it, he is like a man who looks at himself in a mirror
speaker: Narrator

text: and studies himself carefully, and then goes off and immediately forgets what he looks like.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the one who looks at the perfect law of freedom and remains committed to it—thereby demonstrating that he is not a forgetful hearer but a doer of what that law requires—will be blessed in what he does.
speaker: Narrator

text: If anyone thinks that he is religious and does not bridle his tongue, but instead deceives himself, his religion is worthless.
speaker: Narrator

text: A religion that is pure and stainless according to God the Father is this: to take care of orphans and widows who are suffering, and to keep oneself unstained by the world.
speaker: Narrator

text: My brothers, do not let your faith in our glorious Lord Jesus, the Messiah, be tainted by favoritism.
speaker: Narrator

text: Suppose a man wearing gold rings and fine clothes comes into your assembly, and a poor man in dirty clothes also comes in.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you give special attention to the man wearing fine clothes and say, “Please take this seat,” but you say to the poor man, “Stand over there” or “Sit on the floor at my feet,”
speaker: Narrator

text: then you will have made false distinctions among yourselves and will have judged from evil motives, will you not?
speaker: Narrator

text: Listen, my dear brothers! God has chosen the poor in the world to become rich in faith and to be heirs of the kingdom that he promised to those who keep on loving him, has he not?
speaker: Narrator

text: But you have humiliated the man who is poor. Are not rich people the ones who oppress you and drag you into court?
speaker: Narrator

text: Are not they the ones who blaspheme the noble Name by which you have been called?
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, you are doing the right thing if you obey the royal Law in keeping with the Scripture, “You must love your neighbor as yourself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you show partiality, you are committing sin and will be convicted by the Law as violators.
speaker: Narrator

text: For whoever keeps the whole Law but fails in one point is guilty of breaking all of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the one who said, “Never commit adultery,” also said, “Never murder.” Now if you do not commit adultery, but you murder, you become a violator of the Law.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must make it your habit to speak and act like people who are going to be judged by the law of liberty.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the one who has shown no mercy will be judged without mercy. Mercy triumphs over judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: What good does it do, my brothers, if someone claims to have faith but does not prove it with actions? This kind of faith cannot save him, can it?
speaker: Narrator

text: Suppose a brother or sister does not have any clothes or daily food
speaker: Narrator

text: and one of you tells them, “Go in peace! Stay warm and eat heartily.” If you do not provide for their bodily needs, what good does it do?
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way, faith by itself, if it does not prove itself with actions, is dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: But someone may say, “You have faith, and I have actions.” Show me your faith without any actions, and I will show you my faith by my actions.
speaker: Narrator

text: You believe that there is one God. That’s fine! Even the demons believe that and tremble with fear.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do you want proof, you foolish person, that faith without actions is worthless?
speaker: Narrator

text: Our ancestor Abraham was justified by his actions when he offered his son Isaac on the altar, wasn’t he?
speaker: Narrator

text: You see that his faith worked together with what he did, and by his actions his faith was made complete.
speaker: Narrator

text: And so the Scripture was fulfilled that says, “Abraham believed God, and it was credited to him as righteousness.” And so he was called God’s friend.
speaker: Narrator

text: You observe that a person is justified through actions and not through faith alone.
speaker: Narrator

text: Likewise, Rahab the prostitute was justified through actions when she welcomed the messengers and sent them away on a different road, wasn’t she?
speaker: Narrator

text: For just as the body without the spirit is dead, so faith without actions is also dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Not many of you should become teachers, my brothers, because you know that we who teach will be judged more severely than others.
speaker: Narrator

text: For all of us make many mistakes. If someone does not make any mistakes when he speaks, he is perfect and able to control his whole body.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now if we put bits into horses’ mouths to make them obey us, we can guide their whole bodies as well.
speaker: Narrator

text: And look at ships! They are so big that it takes strong winds to drive them, yet they are steered by a tiny rudder wherever the helmsman directs.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way, the tongue is a small part of the body, yet it can boast of great achievements. A huge forest can be set on fire by a little flame.
speaker: Narrator

text: The tongue is a fire, a world of evil. Placed among the parts of our bodies, the tongue contaminates the whole body and sets on fire the course of life, and is itself set on fire by hell.
speaker: Narrator

text: For all kinds of animals, birds, reptiles, and sea creatures can be or have been tamed by humans,
speaker: Narrator

text: but no one can tame the tongue. It is an uncontrollable evil filled with deadly poison.
speaker: Narrator

text: With it we bless the Lord and Father, and with it we curse those who are made in God’s likeness.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the same mouth come blessing and cursing. It should not be like this, my brothers!
speaker: Narrator

text: A spring cannot pour both fresh and brackish water from the same opening, can it?
speaker: Narrator

text: My brothers, a fig tree cannot produce olives, nor a grapevine figs, can it? Neither can a salt spring produce fresh water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who among you is wise and understanding? Let him show by his noble conduct that his actions are done humbly and wisely.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you have bitter jealousy and rivalry in your hearts, stop boasting and slandering the truth.
speaker: Narrator

text: That kind of wisdom does not come from above. No, it is worldly, self-centered, and demonic.
speaker: Narrator

text: For wherever jealousy and rivalry exist, there is disorder and every kind of evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, the wisdom that comes from above is first of all pure, then peace-loving, gentle, willing to yield, full of compassion and good deeds, and without a trace of partiality or hypocrisy.
speaker: Narrator

text: And a harvest of righteousness is grown from the seed of peace planted by peacemakers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Where do those fights and quarrels among you come from? They come from your selfish desires that are at war in your bodies, don’t they?
speaker: Narrator

text: You want something but do not get it, so you commit murder. You covet something but cannot obtain it, so you quarrel and fight. You do not get things because you do not ask for them!
speaker: Narrator

text: You ask for something but do not get it because you ask for it for the wrong reason—for your own pleasure.
speaker: Narrator

text: You adulterers! Don’t you know that friendship with the world means hostility with God? So whoever wants to be a friend of this world is an enemy of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or do you think the Scripture means nothing when it says that the Spirit that God caused to live in us jealously yearns for us?
speaker: Narrator

text:
But he gives all the more grace. And so he says,
“God opposes the arrogant
    but gives grace to the humble.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, submit yourselves to God. Resist the Devil, and he will run away from you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Come close to God, and he will come close to you. Cleanse your hands, you sinners, and purify your hearts, you double-minded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be miserable, mourn, and cry. Let your laughter be turned into mourning, and your joy into gloom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Humble yourselves in the Lord’s presence, and he will exalt you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not criticize each other, brothers. Whoever makes it his habit to criticize his brother or to judge his brother is judging the Law and condemning the Law. But if you condemn the Law, you are not a practicer of the Law but its judge.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is only one Lawgiver and Judge—the one who can save and destroy. So who are you to judge your neighbor?
speaker: Narrator

text: Now listen, you who say, “Today or tomorrow we will go to such and such a town, stay there a year, conduct business, and make money.”
speaker: Narrator

text: You do not know what tomorrow will bring. What is your life? You are a mist that appears for a little while and then vanishes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead you should say, “If the Lord wants us to, we will live—and do this or that.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But you boast about your proud intentions. All such boasting is evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, anyone who knows what is right but fails to do it is guilty of sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now listen, you rich people! Cry and moan over the miseries that are overtaking you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your riches are rotten, your clothes have been eaten by moths,
speaker: Narrator

text: your gold and silver are corroded, and their corrosion will be used as evidence against you and will eat your flesh like fire. You have stored up treasures in these last days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look! The wages that you kept back from the workers who harvested your fields are shouting out against you, and the cries of the reapers have reached the ears of the Lord of the Heavenly Armies.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have lived in luxury and pleasure on earth. You have fattened yourselves for the day of slaughter.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have condemned and murdered the one who is righteous, even though he did not rebel against you.
speaker: Narrator

text: So be patient, brothers, until the coming of the Lord. See how the farmer waits for the precious crop from his land, being patient with it until it receives the fall and the spring rains.
speaker: Narrator

text: You, too, must be patient. Strengthen your hearts, because the coming of the Lord is near.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not complain about each other, brothers, or you will be condemned. Look! The Judge is standing at the door!
speaker: Narrator

text: As an example of suffering and patience, brothers, take the prophets, who spoke in the name of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: We consider those who endured to be blessed. You have heard about Job’s endurance and have seen the purpose of the Lord—that the Lord is compassionate and merciful.
speaker: Narrator

text: Above all, brothers, do not swear oaths by heaven, by earth, or by any other object. Instead, let your “Yes” mean yes and your “No” mean no! Otherwise, you may fall under condemnation.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is anyone among you suffering? He should keep on praying. Is anyone cheerful? He should keep reciting psalms.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is anyone among you sick? He should call for the elders of the church, and they should pray for him and anoint him with oil in the name of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the prayer offered in faith will save the person who is sick. The Lord will raise him up, and if he has committed any sins, he will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, make it your habit to confess your sins to one another and to pray for one another, so that you may be healed. The prayer of a righteous person is powerful and effective.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah was a person just like us, and he prayed earnestly for it not to rain, and rain never came to the land for three years and six months.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he prayed again, and the skies poured out rain, and the ground produced its crops.
speaker: Narrator

text: My brothers, if one of you wanders away from the truth and somebody brings him back,
speaker: Narrator

text: you may be sure that whoever brings a sinner back from his wrong path will save his soul from death and cover a multitude of sins.
speaker: Narrator
